name: LuaSurface.set_tiles
content:
Method: LuaSurface.set_tiles
Description: Set tiles at specified locations. Can automatically correct the edges around modified tiles.

name: LuaSurface.set_tiles
content: Placing a [mineable](runtime:LuaTilePrototype::mineable_properties) tile on top of a non-mineable or [foundation](runtime:LuaTilePrototype::is_foundation) one will turn the latter into the [LuaTile::hidden_tile](runtime:LuaTile::hidden_tile) for that tile. Placing a mineable non-foundation tile on a mineable non-foundation one or a mineable foundation tile on a mineable foundation one will not modify the hidden tile. This restriction can however be circumvented by using

name: LuaSurface.set_tiles
content: tile. This restriction can however be circumvented by using [LuaSurface::set_hidden_tile](runtime:LuaSurface::set_hidden_tile). Placing a non-foundation tile on top of a foundation one when there already exists a hidden tile will push hidden tile to [double hidden](runtime:LuaTile::double_hidden_tile), and foundation tile will turn into hidden. Placing a mineable foundation tile over a mineable non-foundation tile with hidden mineable foundation tile, the hidden tile will be replaced by previously double

name: LuaSurface.set_tiles
content: tile, the hidden tile will be replaced by previously double hidden tile and double hidden tile will be erased. Placing a non-mineable tile will erase hidden and double hidden tiles.

name: LuaSurface.set_tiles
content: It is recommended to call this method once for all the tiles you want to change rather than calling it individually for every tile. As the tile correction is used after every step, calling it one by one could cause the tile correction logic to redo some of the changes. Also, many small API calls are generally more performance intensive than one big one.

name: LuaSurface.set_tiles
content:
Parameters:
- correct_tiles (boolean)[Optional]: If `false`, the correction logic is not applied to the changed tiles. Defaults to `true`.
- player (PlayerIdentification)[Optional]: The player whose undo queue to add these actions to.
- raise_event (boolean)[Optional]: Defaults to `false`.
- remove_colliding_decoratives (boolean)[Optional]: Defaults to `true`.

name: LuaSurface.set_tiles
content:
- remove_colliding_entities ({'complex_type': 'union', 'options': ['boolean', {'complex_type': 'literal', 'value': 'abort_on_collision'}], 'full_format': False})[Optional]: Defaults to `true`.
- tiles ({'complex_type': 'array', 'value': 'Tile'}): 
- undo_index (uint)[Optional]: The index of the undo item to add this action to. An index of `0` creates a new undo item for it. Defaults to putting it into the appropriate undo item automatically if not specified.

name: LuaSurface.set_tiles
content:
Raises:
- script_raised_set_tiles: Raised if the `raise_event` flag was set.

Format:
- {'takes_table': False}

name: LuaSurface.spill_item_stack
content:
Method: LuaSurface.spill_item_stack
Description: Spill items on the ground centered at a given location.

name: LuaSurface.spill_item_stack
content:
Parameters:
- allow_belts (boolean)[Optional]: Whether items can be spilled onto belts. Defaults to `true`.
- enable_looted (boolean)[Optional]: When true, each created item will be flagged with the [LuaEntity::to_be_looted](runtime:LuaEntity::to_be_looted) flag. Defaults to `false`.
- force (ForceID)[Optional]: When provided (and not `nil`) the items will be marked for deconstruction by this force.
- max_radius (double)[Optional]: Max radius from the specified `position` to spill items.

name: LuaSurface.spill_item_stack
content:
- position (MapPosition): Center of the spillage
- stack (ItemStackIdentification): Stack of items to spill
- use_start_position_on_failure (boolean)[Optional]: Allow spilling items at `position` if no non-colliding position is found. Note: Setting to false might cause some items not to be spilled. Defaults to `true`.

name: LuaSurface.spill_item_stack
content:

- {'complex_type': 'array', 'value': 'LuaEntity'}: The created item-on-ground entities.

Format:
- {'takes_table': True, 'table_optional': False}

name: LuaSurface.always_day
content:
Attribute: always_day 
Read_type: boolean
Write_type: boolean
Description: When set to true, the sun will always shine.

name: LuaSurface.brightness_visual_weights
content:
Attribute: brightness_visual_weights 
Read_type: ColorModifier
Write_type: ColorModifier
Description: Defines how surface daytime brightness influences each color channel of the current color lookup table (LUT).

The LUT is multiplied by `((1 - weight) + brightness * weight)` and result is clamped to range `[0, 1]`.

name: LuaSurface.brightness_visual_weights
content:
Default is `{0, 0, 0}`, which means no influence.
Examples: ["```
-- Makes night on the surface pitch black, LuaSurface::min_brightness is set to default value 0.15.
game.surfaces[1].brightness_visual_weights = { 1 / 0.85, 1 / 0.85, 1 / 0.85 }
```"]

name: LuaSurface.darkness
content:
Attribute: darkness 
Read_type: float

Description: Amount of darkness at the current time, as a number in range `[0, 1]`.

name: LuaSurface.dawn

Read_type: double
Write_type: double
Description: The daytime when dawn starts.

name: LuaSurface.daytime

Description: The daytime when dusk starts.

name: LuaSurface.evening

name: LuaSurface.generate_with_lab_tiles
content:

name: LuaSurface.global_effect
content:
Attribute: global_effect [Optional]
Read_type: ModuleEffects
Write_type: ModuleEffects
Description: Surface-wide effects applied to entities with effect receivers. May be `nil` if surface is not using surface-wide effect source.

name: LuaSurface.has_global_electric_network
content:
Attribute: has_global_electric_network 
Read_type: boolean

Description: Whether this surface currently has a global electric network.

name: LuaSurface.ignore_surface_conditions
content:
Attribute: ignore_surface_conditions 
Read_type: boolean
Write_type: boolean
Description: If surface condition checks should not be performed on this surface.

name: LuaSurface.index
content:
Attribute: index 
Read_type: uint

Description: This surface's index in [LuaGameScript::surfaces](runtime:LuaGameScript::surfaces) (unique ID). It is assigned when a surface is created, and remains so until it is [deleted](runtime:on_surface_deleted). Indexes of deleted surfaces can be reused.

name: LuaSurface.localised_name
content:
Attribute: localised_name [Optional]
Read_type: LocalisedString
Write_type: LocalisedString
Description: Localised name of this surface. When set, will replace the internal surface name in places where a player sees surface name.

Value may be ignored if a surface has a SpacePlatform or Planet object attached to it, which take the precedence.

name: LuaSurface.map_gen_settings
content:
Attribute: map_gen_settings 
Read_type: MapGenSettings
Write_type: MapGenSettings
Description: The generation settings for this surface. These can be modified after surface generation, but note that this will not retroactively update the surface. To manually regenerate it, [LuaSurface::regenerate_entity](runtime:LuaSurface::regenerate_entity), [LuaSurface::regenerate_decorative](runtime:LuaSurface::regenerate_decorative), and [LuaSurface::delete_chunk](runtime:LuaSurface::delete_chunk) can be used.

name: LuaSurface.min_brightness
content:
Attribute: min_brightness 
Read_type: double
Write_type: double
Description: The minimal brightness during the night. Defaults to `0.15`. This has an effect on both rendering and game mechanics such as biter spawns and solar power.

name: LuaSurface.morning
content:
Attribute: morning 
Read_type: double
Write_type: double
Description: The daytime when morning starts.

name: LuaSurface.name
content:
Attribute: name 
Read_type: string
Write_type: string
Description: The name of this surface. Names are unique among surfaces.

The default surface can't be renamed.

name: LuaSurface.no_enemies_mode
content:
Attribute: no_enemies_mode 
Read_type: boolean
Write_type: boolean
Description: Is no-enemies mode enabled on this surface?

name: LuaSurface.object_name
content:

name: LuaTile

name: LuaTile.cancel_deconstruction
content:
Method: LuaTile.cancel_deconstruction
Description: Cancels deconstruction if it is scheduled, does nothing otherwise.

Parameters:
- force (ForceID): The force who did the deconstruction order.
- player (PlayerIdentification)[Optional]: The player to set the last_user to if any.

Raises:

Format:
- {'takes_table': False}

name: LuaTile.collides_with

Examples:
```
-- Check if the character would collide with a tile
game.player.print(tostring(game.player.surface.get_tile(1, 1).collides_with("player")))
```

name: LuaTile.double_hidden_tile

Description: The name of the [LuaTilePrototype](runtime:LuaTilePrototype) double hidden under this tile or `nil` if there is no double hidden tile.

During normal gameplay, only [non-mineable](runtime:LuaTilePrototype::mineable_properties) tiles can become double hidden. This can however be circumvented with [LuaSurface::set_double_hidden_tile](runtime:LuaSurface::set_double_hidden_tile).

name: LuaTrain.locomotives
content:

-- called on a LuaTrain with 3 locomotives, it returns 3 LuaEntities:
train.locomotives -- => {front_movers = {loco1, loco2}, back_movers = {loco3}}

name: LuaTrainManager
content:
Class: LuaTrainManager
Description: The train manager manages all the train in the game. LuaTrainManager allows to perform some direct queries to the train manager.

There is always exactly one train manager instance in a game, it can be obtained from [LuaGameScript::train_manager](runtime:LuaGameScript::train_manager). This object is always valid and is equal to any other instance of LuaTrainManager from this game.

name: LuaTrainManager.get_train_by_id

Method: LuaTrainManager.get_train_by_id
Description: Searches for a train with given ID.

Parameters:
- train_id (uint): Train ID to search

Returns:
- LuaTrain: Train if found

Format:
- {'takes_table': False}

name: LuaTrainManager.get_train_stops

Description: Gets all train stops that pass given filter

Parameters:

Returns:
- {'complex_type': 'array', 'value': 'LuaEntity'}: 

Format:
- {'takes_table': False}

name: LuaTrainManager.get_trains
content:

Parameters:

Returns:
- {'complex_type': 'array', 'value': 'LuaTrain'}:

name: LuaTrainManager.request_train_path
content:
Method: LuaTrainManager.request_train_path
Description: Direct access to train pathfinder. Allows to search rail paths or querying which stops are accessible

name: LuaTrainManager.request_train_path
content:
Parameters:
- goals ({'complex_type': 'array', 'value': 'TrainPathFinderGoal'}): 
- in_chain_signal_section (boolean)[Optional]: Defaults to `false`. If set to true, pathfinder will not return a path that cannot have its start immediately reserved. A path that cannot have its start immediately reserved could cause a train to stop inside of an intersection.

name: LuaTrainManager.request_train_path
content: - return_path (boolean)[Optional]: Only relevant if request type is `"path"`. Returning a full path is expensive due to multiple LuaEntity created. In order for path to be returned, true must be provided here. Defaults to false in which case a path will not be provided.

name: LuaTrainManager.request_train_path
content: - search_direction ({'complex_type': 'union', 'options': [{'complex_type': 'literal', 'value': 'respect-movement-direction'}, {'complex_type': 'literal', 'value': 'any-direction-with-locomotives'}], 'full_format': False})[Optional]: Only relevant if `starts` was not provided in which case 2 starts (front and back) are deduced from the train. Selects which train ends should be considered as starts. Defaults to `"any-direction-with-locomotives"`.

name: LuaTrainManager.request_train_path
content:
- shortest_path (boolean)[Optional]: Defaults to `false`. If set to true, only length of rails is added to penalties causing search to look for shortest path (not smallest penalty)
- starts ({'complex_type': 'array', 'value': 'RailEndStart'})[Optional]: Manually provided starting positions.
- steps_limit (uint)[Optional]: Maximum amount of steps pathfinder is allowed to perform.

name: LuaTrainManager.request_train_path
content:
- train (LuaTrain)[Optional]: Mandatory if `starts` is not provided, optional otherwise. Selects a context for the pathfinder to decide which train to exclude from penalties and which signals are considered possible to reacquire. If `starts` is not provided, then it is also used to collect front and back ends for the search
- type (TrainPathRequestType)[Optional]: Request type. Determines the return type of the method. Defaults to `"path"`.

name: LuaTrainManager.request_train_path
content:
Returns:
- {'complex_type': 'union', 'options': ['TrainPathFinderOneGoalResult', 'TrainPathAllGoalsResult'], 'full_format': False}: The type of the returned value depends on `type`.

Format:
- {'takes_table': True, 'table_optional': False}

name: LuaUndoRedoStack.valid
content:
Attribute: valid 
Read_type: boolean

Description: Is this object valid? This Lua object holds a reference to an object within the game engine. It is possible that the game-engine object is removed whilst a mod still holds the corresponding Lua object. If that happens, the object becomes invalid, i.e. this attribute will be `false`. Mods are advised to check for object validity if any change to the game state might have occurred between the creation of the Lua object and its access.

name: LuaWireConnector
content:
Class: LuaWireConnector
Description: A wire connector of a given entity. Allows to find wires, add or remove wires and do some basic operations specific to those connectors.

name: LuaWireConnector.can_wire_reach
content:
Method: LuaWireConnector.can_wire_reach
Description: Checks if a wire can reach from this connector to the other connector.

Parameters:
- other_connector ({'complex_type': 'union', 'options': ['LuaWireConnector', 'LuaEntity'], 'full_format': False}): Target to which a wire reach is to be checked.

Returns:
- boolean: 

Format:
- {'takes_table': False}

name: LuaWireConnector.connect_to
content:
Method: LuaWireConnector.connect_to
Description: Connects this connector to other wire connector.

Parameters:
- origin (defines.wire_origin)[Optional]: Origin of the wire. Defaults to `defines.wire_origin.player`.
- reach_check (boolean)[Optional]: True by default. For wires out of reach or on different surfaces, `false` must be provided.
- target (LuaWireConnector): Other connector to which a wire should be added.

Returns:
- boolean: Whether a connection was made.

Format:
- {'takes_table': False}

name: LuaWireConnector.disconnect_all
content:
Method: LuaWireConnector.disconnect_all
Description: Removes all wires going out of this wire connector.

Parameters:
- origin (defines.wire_origin)[Optional]: Origin of the wires to remove. Defaults to `defines.wire_origin.player`.

Returns:
- boolean: True if any wire was removed.

Format:
- {'takes_table': False}

name: LuaWireConnector.disconnect_from
content:
Method: LuaWireConnector.disconnect_from
Description: Disconnects this connector from other wire connector.

Parameters:
- origin (defines.wire_origin)[Optional]: Origin of the wire. Defaults to `defines.wire_origin.player`.
- target (LuaWireConnector): Other connector to which wire to be removed should be removed.

Returns:
- boolean: Whether a connection was removed.

Format:
- {'takes_table': False}

name: LuaWireConnector.have_common_neighbour
content:
Method: LuaWireConnector.have_common_neighbour
Description: Checks if this and other wire connector have a common neighbour.

Parameters:
- ignore_ghost_neighbours (boolean)[Optional]: 
- other_connector (LuaWireConnector): Other connector to check for common neighbour.

Returns:
- boolean: 

Format:
- {'takes_table': False}

name: LuaWireConnector.is_connected_to
content:
Method: LuaWireConnector.is_connected_to
Description: Checks if this connector has any wire going to the other connector.

Parameters:
- origin (defines.wire_origin)[Optional]: Origin of the wire. Defaults to `defines.wire_origin.player`.
- target (LuaWireConnector): Other connector to check for a connection to.

Returns:
- boolean: 

Format:
- {'takes_table': False}

name: LuaWireConnector.connection_count
content:
Attribute: connection_count 
Read_type: uint

Description: Amount of wires going out of this connector. It includes all wires (ghost wires and real wires).

name: LuaWireConnector.connections
LuaWireConnector.is_ghost
content:
Attribute: is_ghost 
Read_type: boolean

Description: If this connector is owned by an entity inside of a ghost. If any of 2 ends of a wire attaches to a ghost connector, then a wire is considered to be a ghost.

name: LuaWireConnector.network_id
content:
Attribute: network_id 
Read_type: uint

Description: Index of a CircuitNetwork or ElectricSubNetwork which is going through this wire connector. Returns 0 if there is no network associated with this wire connector right now. CircuitNetwork indexes are independent of indexes of ElectricSubNetwork so they may collide with each other.

name: LuaWireConnector.object_name
content:
Attribute: object_name 
Read_type: string

Description: The class name of this object. Available even when `valid` is false. For LuaStruct objects it may also be suffixed with a dotted path to a member of the struct.

name: LuaWireConnector.owner
content:
Attribute: owner 
Read_type: LuaEntity

Description: The entity this wire connector belongs to. May return entity ghost instead if this wire connector belongs to inner entity.

name: LuaWireConnector.real_connection_count
content:
Attribute: real_connection_count 
Read_type: uint

Description: Amount of real wires going out of this connector. It only includes wires for which both wire connectors are real.

name: CustomInputEvent
content:
Event: CustomInputEvent
Description: Called when a [CustomInputPrototype](prototype:CustomInputPrototype) is activated.
Examples: ["```
-- This will be raised when a custom input with the name "my-potato-control" and action "lua" is pressed
script.on_event("my-potato-control", function(event)
  game.print("Keyboard shortcut pressed on tick: " ..tostring(event.tick))
end)
```"]

name: on_object_destroyed
content:
Event: on_object_destroyed
Description: Called after an object is destroyed which was registered with [LuaBootstrap::register_on_object_destroyed](runtime:LuaBootstrap::register_on_object_destroyed) previously.

Depending on when a given object is destroyed, this event will be fired at the end of the current tick or at the end of the next tick. The event's timing is independent of the in-world object being destroyed.

name: name
content:
Data: name 
Type: defines.events
Description: Identifier of the event

name: registration_number
content:
Data: registration_number 
Type: uint64
Description: The number returned by [register_on_object_destroyed](runtime:LuaBootstrap::register_on_object_destroyed) to uniquely identify this object during this event.

name: tick
content:
Data: tick 
Type: uint
Description: Tick the event was generated.

name: type
content:
Data: type 
Type: defines.target_type
Description: Type of the object that was destroyed. Same as third value returned by [LuaBootstrap::register_on_object_destroyed](runtime:LuaBootstrap::register_on_object_destroyed)

name: useful_id
content:
Data: useful_id 
Type: uint64
Description: The [useful identifier](runtime:RegistrationTarget) of the object. Same as second value returned by [LuaBootstrap::register_on_object_destroyed](runtime:LuaBootstrap::register_on_object_destroyed)

Description: Called when the player flips an entity. This event is only fired when the entity actually changes its orientation or mirroring, so it won't be triggered when pressing the flip keys on an entity that can't be flipped.

This event reflects a change in the [LuaEntity::mirroring](runtime:LuaEntity::mirroring) property.

Description: The enacted flip. `true` means a horizontal flip, `false` a vertical one.

name: on_player_mined_entity
content:
Event: on_player_mined_entity
Description: Called after the results of an entity being mined are collected just before the entity is destroyed.

After this event any items in the buffer will be transferred into the player as if they came from mining the entity.

The buffer inventory is special in that it's only valid during this event and has a dynamic size expanding as more items are transferred into it.

name: on_robot_mined_entity

Event: on_robot_mined_entity
Description: Called after the results of an entity being mined are collected just before the entity is destroyed.

After this event any items in the buffer will be transferred into the robot as if they came from mining the entity.

The buffer inventory is special in that it's only valid during this event and has a dynamic size expanding as more items are transferred into it.

Concept: ChunkPosition
Description: Coordinates of a chunk in a [LuaSurface](runtime:LuaSurface) where each integer `x`/`y` represents a different chunk. This uses the same format as [MapPosition](runtime:MapPosition), meaning it can be specified either with or without explicit keys. A [MapPosition](runtime:MapPosition) can be translated to a ChunkPosition by dividing the `x`/`y` values by 32.

Concept: Color
Description: Red, green, blue and alpha values, all in range [0, 1] or all in range [0, 255] if any value is > 1. All values here are optional. Color channels default to `0`, the alpha channel defaults to `1`.

name: Color
content: Similar to [MapPosition](runtime:MapPosition), Color allows the short-hand notation of passing an array of exactly 3 or 4 numbers. The game usually expects colors to be in pre-multiplied form (color channels are pre-multiplied by alpha).

name: EnemyExpansionMapSettings
content:
Concept: EnemyExpansionMapSettings
Description: Candidate chunks are given scores to determine which one of them should be expanded into. This score takes into account various settings noted below. The iteration is over a square region centered around the chunk for which the calculation is done, and includes the central chunk as well. Distances are calculated as [Manhattan distance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taxicab_geometry).

The pseudocode algorithm to determine a chunk's score is as follows:

name: EnemyExpansionMapSettings
content:
```
player = 0
for neighbour in all chunks within enemy_building_influence_radius from chunk:
  player += number of player buildings on neighbour
    * building_coefficient
    * neighbouring_chunk_coefficient^distance(chunk, neighbour)
base = 0
for neighbour in all chunk within friendly_base_influence_radius from chunk:
  base += num of enemy bases on neighbour
    * other_base_coefficient
    * neighbouring_base_chunk_coefficient^distance(chunk, neighbour)
score(chunk) = 1 / (1 + player + base)
```

Defaults to `0.9`, or 90%.', 'type': 'double', 'optional': False}, {'name': 'max_expansion_cooldown', 'order': 12, 'description': 'The maximum time between expansions

Defaults to `7`.", 'type': 'uint', 'optional': False}, {'name': 'min_expansion_cooldown', 'order': 11, 'description':

name: LocalisedString
content:
Concept: LocalisedString
Description: Localised strings are a way to support translation of in-game text. It is an array where the first element is the key and the remaining elements are parameters that will be substituted for placeholders in the template designated by the key.

The key identifies the string template. For example, `"gui-alert-tooltip.attack"` (for the template `"__1__ objects are being damaged"`; see the file `data/core/locale/en.cfg`).

name: LocalisedString
content: The template can contain placeholders such as `__1__` or `__2__`. These will be replaced by the respective parameter in the LocalisedString. The parameters themselves can be other localised strings, which will be processed recursively in the same fashion. Localised strings can not be recursed deeper than 20 levels and can not have more than 20 parameters.

name: LocalisedString
content: There are two special flags for the localised string, indicated by the key being a particular string. First, if the key is the empty string (`""`), then all parameters will be concatenated (after processing, if any are localised strings themselves). Second, if the key is a question mark (`"?"`), then the first valid parameter will be used. A parameter can be invalid if its name doesn't match any string template. If no parameters are valid, the last one is returned. This is useful to implement a fallback

name: LocalisedString
content: last one is returned. This is useful to implement a fallback for missing locale templates.

name: LocalisedString
content:
Furthermore, when an API function expects a localised string, it will also accept a regular string (i.e. not a table) which will not be translated, as well as a number, boolean or `nil`, which will be converted to their textual representation.
Complex_type: {'complex_type': 'union', 'options': ['string', 'number', 'boolean', 'LuaObject', 'nil', {'complex_type': 'array', 'value': 'LocalisedString'}], 'full_format': False}

name: MapGenSize
content:
Concept: MapGenSize
Description: A floating point number specifying an amount.

For backwards compatibility, MapGenSizes can also be specified as a string, which will be converted to a number (when queried, a number will always be returned).

name: MapGenSize
content: The map generation algorithm officially supports the range of values the in-game map generation screen shows (specifically `0` and values from `1/6` to `6`). Values outside this range are not guaranteed to work as expected.

name: MapPosition
content:
Concept: MapPosition
Description: Coordinates on a surface, for example of an entity. MapPositions may be specified either as a dictionary with `x`, `y` as keys, or simply as an array with two elements.

name: MapPosition
content:
The coordinates are saved as a fixed-size 32 bit integer, with 8 bits reserved for decimal precision, meaning the smallest value step is `1/2^8 = 0.00390625` tiles.

name: MarketIngredient
MathExpression
content:
Concept: MathExpression
Description: A string that represents a math expression. The expression parser recognizes four basic token types (with their regex):

- Whitespace: `[ \n\r\t]*`

- Number: `(0x[0-9a-f]+|([0-9]+\.?[0-9]*|\.[0-9]+)(e-?[0-9]+)?)` (e.g. `3.2`, `100`, `.6`, `4.2e-5`, `0x2a5f`). Supports hexadecimal input and scientific notation for decimal numbers.

- Operator: `+`, `-`, `*`, `/`, `^`, and `()` for brackets, which may be nested.

name: MathExpression
content:
- Identifier: The functions listed below and any variables listed where the expression is used.

Identifiers are used to name functions and variables, which result in or represent numbers. The following functions are always available:

- `abs(value)`: Returns absolute value of the given argument; i.e. if the argument is negative, it is inverted.

- `log2(value)`: Returns a binary logarithm of the given value.

name: MathExpression
content:
- `sign(value)`: Returns `-1` for negative numbers, `0` for zero (regardless of sign), `1` for positive numbers

- `max(value1, value2, ...)`: Returns the greater of the given values. Supports between 2 and 255 arguments.

- `min(value1, value2, ...)`: Returns the smaller of the given values. Supports between 2 and 255 arguments.

name: MathExpression
content:
The property where the expression is used may provide variables. For example in [TechnologyUnit::count_formula](prototype:TechnologyUnit::count_formula) `L` and `l` may be used for the technology level.

The formula is executed following the [BODMAS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_of_operations#Conventional_order) order (also known as PEMDAS).
Complex_type: string

name: RangeMode
RealOrientation
content:
Concept: RealOrientation
Description: The smooth orientation. It is a [float](runtime:float) in the range `[0, 1)` that covers a full circle, starting at the top and going clockwise. This means a value of `0` indicates "north", a value of `0.5` indicates "south".

For example then, a value of `0.625` would indicate "south-west", and a value of `0.875` would indicate "north-west".
Complex_type: float

name: boolean
double
float
int
content:
Concept: int
Description: 32-bit signed integer. Possible values are `-2 147 483 648` to `2 147 483 647`.

Since Lua 5.2 only uses doubles, any API that asks for `int` will floor the given double.
Complex_type: {'complex_type': 'builtin'}

name: int8
content:
Concept: int8
Description: 8-bit signed integer. Possible values are `-128` to `127`.

Since Lua 5.2 only uses doubles, any API that asks for `int8` will floor the given double.
Complex_type: {'complex_type': 'builtin'}

name: nil
number
string
table
content:
Concept: table
Description: Tables are enclosed in curly brackets, like this `{}`.

Throughout the API docs, the terms "array" and "dictionary" are used. These are fundamentally just [Lua tables](http://www.lua.org/pil/2.5.html), but have a limitation on which kind of table keys can be used. An array is a table that uses continuous integer keys starting at `1`, while a dictionary can use numeric or string keys in any order or combination.
Complex_type: {'complex_type': 'builtin'}

name: uint
content:
Concept: uint
Description: 32-bit unsigned integer. Possible values are `0` to `4 294 967 295`.

Since Lua 5.2 only uses doubles, any API that asks for `uint` will floor the given double.
Complex_type: {'complex_type': 'builtin'}

name: uint16
content:
Concept: uint16
Description: 16-bit unsigned integer. Possible values are `0` to `65 535`.

Since Lua 5.2 only uses doubles, any API that asks for `uint16` will floor the given double.
Complex_type: {'complex_type': 'builtin'}

name: uint64
content:
Concept: uint64
Description: 64-bit unsigned integer. Possible values are `0` to `18 446 744 073 709 551 615`.

Since Lua 5.2 only uses doubles, any API that asks for `uint64` will floor the given double.
Complex_type: {'complex_type': 'builtin'}

name: uint8
content:
Concept: uint8
Description: 8-bit unsigned integer. Possible values are `0` to `255`.

Since Lua 5.2 only uses doubles, any API that asks for `uint8` will floor the given double.
Complex_type: {'complex_type': 'builtin'}

name: rocket_silo_status
content:
Define: rocket_silo_status
Description: The various parts of the launch sequence of the rocket silo.

name: arms_advance
content:
Value: arms_advance
Description: The next state is `rocket_ready` or if the rocket is destroyed in this state then the next state will be `lights_blinking_close`. The rocket is getting prepared for launch.

name: arms_retract
content:
Value: arms_retract
Description: The next state is `rocket_flying` or if the rocket is destroyed in this state then the next state will be `lights_blinking_close`. The rocket is getting launched.

name: building_rocket
content:
Value: building_rocket
Description: The rocket silo is crafting rocket parts. When there are enough rocket parts, the silo will switch into the `create_rocket` state.

name: create_rocket
content:
Value: create_rocket
Description: The next state is `lights_blinking_open`. The rocket silo rocket entity gets created.

name: doors_closing
content:
Value: doors_closing
Description: The next state is `building_rocket`.

name: doors_opened
content:
Value: doors_opened
Description: The next state is `rocket_rising` or if the rocket is destroyed in this state then the next state will be `lights_blinking_close`. The rocket is getting prepared for launch.

name: doors_opening
content:
Value: doors_opening
Description: The next state is `doors_opened`. The rocket is getting prepared for launch.

name: engine_starting
content:
Value: engine_starting
Description: The next state is `arms_retract` or if the rocket is destroyed in this state then the next state will be `lights_blinking_close`. The rocket is getting launched.

name: launch_started
content:
Value: launch_started
Description: The next state is `engine_starting` or if the rocket is destroyed in this state then the next state will be `lights_blinking_close`. The rocket is getting launched.

name: launch_starting
content:
Value: launch_starting
Description: The next state is `launch_started`.

name: lights_blinking_close
content:
Value: lights_blinking_close
Description: The next state is `doors_closing`.

name: lights_blinking_open
content:
Value: lights_blinking_open
Description: The next state is `doors_opening`. The rocket is getting prepared for launch.

name: rocket_flying
content:
Value: rocket_flying
Description: The next state is `lights_blinking_close`. The rocket is getting launched.

name: rocket_ready
content:
Value: rocket_ready
Description: The rocket launch can be started by the player. When the launch is started, the silo switches into the `launch_starting` state.

name: rocket_rising
content:
Value: rocket_rising
Description: The next state is `arms_advance` or if the rocket is destroyed in this state then the next state will be `lights_blinking_close`. The rocket is getting prepared for launch.
